entry.et: Middle English, from Anglo-French uniter, from Latin unitus, past participle of unire, from unus one one

def.dt: :to put together to form a single unit
:to link by a legal or moral bond
:to become one or as if one
:to become combined by or as if by adhesion or mixture

entry.et: obsolete unite united, from Middle English unit, from Latin unitus, past participle

def.dt: :an old British gold 20-shilling piece issued first by James I in 1604 for the newly united England and Scotland called also Jacobus
